fear-led management destroys culture, drains performance, and costs companies their best people.\",\"body_html\":\" A lot of people misunderstand workplace abuse and emotional manipulation as motivation. Read that again. I\u2019ve seen leaders who believe fear is fuel. Who confuse control for culture. Who think metrics are the only map they need. And yes, those leaders can get short-term results. But long-term? It\u2019s a house of cards. Photo by Ryan Moulton on Unsplash The End of Fear-Led Systems People today are done with fear-led leadership. You see it in the streets as much as in boardrooms\u2014marches for light, meaning, justice, and joy. Why would anyone clock in every day for environments that feel darker? That old model \u2014 Gordon Gekko swagger, Wolf of Wall Street bravado \u2014 thrived on fear and audacity. But future generations won\u2019t tolerate it. Millennials and Gen Z are accountability-centric. They\u2019ll leave. They\u2019ll walk. They\u2019ll build or find systems that actually value them. Fear Drains Performance Fear-based management doesn\u2019t just hurt feelings; it wrecks performance. \uD83D\uDCCA APA (2023): 77% of employees experience work-related stress, and nearly 60% report negative impacts on mental health. Burnout is not a buzzword. It\u2019s a business liability. Photo by Larry Nalzaro on Unsplash Fear Drains Performance Fear-based management doesn\u2019t just hurt feelings; it wrecks performance. \uD83D\uDCCA APA (2023): 77% of employees experience work-related stress, and nearly 60% report negative impacts on mental health. Burnout is not a buzzword. It\u2019s a business liability. Radical Transparency Here\u2019s my proposal: tell the truth up front. If your company is going to treat people like expendable parts, say it. If you know people will leave in two years because your infrastructure is rigid, say it. If you don\u2019t intend to prioritize employee growth, say it. At least then, people can decide with eyes open. They can prepare themselves. They won\u2019t walk away saying, \u201CDang it, they almost got me again.\u201D That level of honesty could reset the relationship between work and workers. Building Cultures That Last Because here\u2019s the reality: Passion is fuel. Integrity is alignment. Care is strategy. You can hit profits and KPIs without cruelty. You can drive performance without breaking people. \uD83D\uDCCA Deloitte Human Capital Trends (2023): Organizations prioritizing human sustainability are 2.2x more likely to outperform financially. When leadership is grounded in something deeper than fear, you stop mistaking manipulation for motivation\u2014and start building cultures that actually last. If this hit home, it might be time to assess your own culture. Check out True People Consulting\u2019s CultureShift Diagnostic\u2122 \u2014a framework designed to surface hidden costs of fear and chart a better way forward. \",\"truncated_body_text\":\"A lot of people misunderstand workplace abuse and emotional manipulation as motivation. key_insights: Fear-based management creates short-term results but long-term organizational damage
77% of employees experience work-related stress with 60% reporting negative mental health impacts (APA 2023)
Millennials and Gen Z prioritize accountability and will leave fear-led environments
Organizations prioritizing human sustainability are 2.2x more likely to outperform financially (Deloitte 2023)
Radical transparency about workplace culture can reset employer-employee relationships
Passion, integrity, and care are strategic business advantages, not soft skills
Fear-based leadership is incompatible with sustainable high performance
The traditional 'Gordon Gekko' leadership model is becoming obsolete
summary: This article critiques fear-based management practices and argues that leadership grounded in fear destroys workplace culture, drains performance, and drives away talent. The author presents data showing that workplace stress affects 77% of employees and that organizations prioritizing human sustainability outperform competitors by 2.2x. The piece advocates for radical transparency in workplace expectations and demonstrates that sustainable high performance requires leadership based on passion, integrity, and genuine care rather than control and manipulation.

Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon The Spark Left My Eyes: What Burnout Taught Me About the System That‚Äôs Making Us Sick Samantha Truman 10 min read ¬∑ 5 days ago -- Listen Share What burnout taught me about the system that‚Äôs making us sick. W hen I finally made it to the top, I didn‚Äôt feel proud. I felt sick. I remember looking in the mirror ‚Äî 190 pounds, heart failing, the spark gone from my eyes. The paychecks were good. The travel, the clothes, the cars, the house ‚Äî all there. But the light was gone. And that was the moment I realized: the problem wasn‚Äôt money. It was the system. The infrastructure. The way things are built in our workplaces and in our societies. Because when I looked around, I saw sickness everywhere. People smiling while silently dying inside. Burnout. Isolation. Absurd health conditions. Shortened lives. People working themselves into the ground and still struggling to afford a decent meal. You can‚Äôt convince me this is what God had in mind for us. You can‚Äôt tell me a loving God designed a world where joy is a luxury and exhaustion is proof of worth. That‚Äôs when it hit me ‚Äî the system isn‚Äôt broken. It‚Äôs working. It was built to function this way: extractive, performative, and indifferent to the human condition. Press enter or click to view image in full size The windmills in Pirogovo, Ukraine ‚Äî where the sky is impossibly blue and endlessly wide, a reminder of what still matters when everything else falls away. And it‚Äôs not just one industry. I‚Äôve worked across them all ‚Äî healthcare, tech, education, corporate. I‚Äôve facilitated to over twenty thousand people, advised executive leaders, sat in rooms where everyone talked about innovation but no one talked about humanity. No matter where I went, the sickness followed. Different offices, same symptoms. Because people are people ‚Äî and when systems are sick, people suffer. I‚Äôve mastered the hustle. I‚Äôve studied it from every angle ‚Äî as the employee, the consultant, the executive, the founder. And the hardest life lesson I‚Äôve learned is this: if you don‚Äôt know where you‚Äôre going, you‚Äôll end up lost ‚Äî sometimes in a corner of your own making. I got lost inside achievement. I got lost inside perfection. I got lost inside systems that rewarded my silence and called it professionalism. And when I finally saw how unrecognizable I‚Äôd become, I had to ask myself: how did the system transform me? How did I let it dim my light, drain my spirit, erase my essence ‚Äî and for what? A paycheck? A car? A title? It wasn‚Äôt worth it. Because no matter how far I climbed, I couldn‚Äôt escape the truth: we‚Äôre building lives inside infrastructures that were never built for our well-being. And I refuse to perform wellness for systems that make people sick. I want to build happy people and happy systems. That‚Äôs what my work whispers beneath it all. That‚Äôs the call. Because if you want to see better, you have to be willing to look at the rot. And most people don‚Äôt want to go there. But that‚Äôs where the real work begins. The System That Made Me Sick: How Work Lost Its Humanity It didn‚Äôt matter where I went ‚Äî tech, healthcare, corporate, nonprofits ‚Äî the same sickness followed. Different names, same disease. I‚Äôve been in so many organizations, dissected them from the inside, and no matter how fancy the strategy deck, the truth is always the same: people are people, and most systems are sick. I first realized it when I looked around and noticed how much pain we‚Äôve normalized. This when I realized that we are entering the 2030 Renaissance . Suicide rates high. Burnout everywhere. You can‚Äôt even walk into a supermarket and buy a healthy meal half the time because people are living paycheck to paycheck. Press enter or click to view image in full size Portland, Jamaica ‚Äî the place that taught me the system was never just corporate. It was cultural. Generational. Colonial. And it still shapes how we work today. The system works exactly as it was built to ‚Äî extractive, performative, and indifferent to the soul. It‚Äôs not broken. It was designed this way. And I‚Äôve been in enough rooms to know: most people aren‚Äôt ready to face that truth. Because if they did, they‚Äôd have to change something. When I first entered the culture industry and specialized in DEI, I thought I‚Äôd finally found my people. Finally, we were talking about harm, about invisibility, about the weight that underrepresented people carry. I thought, yes, this is the work. But then I started to see the same patterns repeating ‚Äî the same corporate performance, the same fear of real accountability, the same obsession with language and optics while people on the ground were still breaking. You can‚Äôt decorate decay. You have to name it. You have to face it. And when you do, you realize most of our workplaces are just mirrors of society: beautiful from afar, corroded underneath. I‚Äôve sat with executives who talk about ‚Äútransformation‚Äù but refuse to give up control. I‚Äôve seen people say they want change, but not costly change. I‚Äôve watched good people silence themselves because speaking the truth might cost them their position, their reputation, or their peace. So no, the problem isn‚Äôt just cultural ‚Äî it‚Äôs spiritual. And that‚Äôs why I do what I do. The Survival: Living Through the Workplace Burnout Epidemic Before I built systems, I survived them. I was born in Ukraine to a Ukrainian mother and a Jamaican father. Then moved to Jamaica with a professional tyrant for a father ‚Äî cunning, volatile, and cruel. My childhood was a masterclass in adaptation. I learned early that survival meant reading the room, staying quiet, moving strategically. Eventually, I made it to California at fourteen with my mother and Palestinian stepfather ‚Äî silenced, shape-shifting to fit the world around me. I buried my accent for safety. Wore the same clothes week after week. Tried to pass. Tried to belong. Tried to disappear just enough to survive. I had grit. That was never the problem. It‚Äôs what kept me alive. By sixteen, I shaved my head. I needed a purge. By seventeen, I was homeless. And still, I fought. Because even then, I could imagine a future better than the one I was living I became a filmmaker. Then a shopping host on cruise ships. A flight attendant. A consultant. A corporate leader. Now, a founder. I‚Äôve lived in every layer of the hierarchy ‚Äî from paycheck-to-paycheck employee to executive insider. And what I learned at every level is this: the sickness doesn‚Äôt discriminate. It just changes clothes. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman, producing her first feature film at 18. Before the deadlines, the deliverables, the exhaustion ‚Äî before the spark began to slip away. I‚Äôve seen it in blue-collar workers afraid to call in sick. In executives terrified to be seen as human. In young people confusing busyness with purpose. In elders counting down to retirement like it‚Äôs salvation. I‚Äôve lived it too ‚Äî the performing, the over-giving, the disappearing. The slow erasure of self in systems that call it ambition. And then one day, my body rebelled. Heart failure. Ten years of undiagnosed hypertension. My body had been whispering for years, but I was too busy proving myself to listen. When it finally screamed, I had to. That‚Äôs when I realized: the system isn‚Äôt only outside of us ‚Äî it‚Äôs inside of us. It‚Äôs the voices that say ‚Äúwork harder.‚Äù It‚Äôs the fear that if you slow down, you‚Äôll lose your worth. It‚Äôs the conditioning that tells you to hide the parts that don‚Äôt look like power. So I stopped. I stopped performing survival. I stopped making myself smaller for systems that couldn‚Äôt hold me. I stopped calling sickness ‚Äúsuccess.‚Äù And I made a decision: if the world was going to keep building systems that break people, I‚Äôd spend the rest of my life building systems that breathe. Because I‚Äôve lived what happens when we don‚Äôt. I‚Äôve been the girl who had nothing. The woman who had everything. And the human who realized that both are empty if you‚Äôve lost your soul in the process. The Surrender: Redefining Success, Rest, and Human-Centered Leadership At some point, the fight has to stop. Not because you‚Äôve lost ‚Äî but because you‚Äôve finally realized you don‚Äôt have to fight yourself to live. In 2025, I walked away from an executive role to focus on building for the future. Not someone else‚Äôs future ‚Äî mine. Humanity‚Äôs. For the first time, I stopped running long enough to look in the mirror and really see. I did an exercise I now call ‚Äúthe good, the bad, and the ugly.‚Äù The ‚Äúugly‚Äù section was so long it scared me. It was a mirror I couldn‚Äôt look away from. Every mistake, every betrayal, every way I‚Äôd silenced myself, every version of me that had learned to perform strength because no one ever taught her safety. And instead of editing it, I faced it. That version of me ‚Äî the one who could finally look at everything ‚Äî surrendered. Not to defeat, but to truth. Because sometimes the ugliest parts of you are the ones that most need your compassion. You don‚Äôt heal by hiding what happened. You heal by accepting it, naming it, and releasing the shame attached to it. Press enter or click to view image in full size Lisbon, Portugal ‚Äî Samantha Truman with her then-toddler. Another beautiful escape that couldn‚Äôt fix what she refused to face. That‚Äôs what surrender was for me ‚Äî the choice to stop running from myself. It didn‚Äôt mean smiling through it. It meant standing in the middle of it and saying, yes, this happened. And it‚Äôs not all of who I am. Because when the spark leaves your eyes, you have to fight to get it back. And the first fight isn‚Äôt with the world ‚Äî it‚Äôs with yourself. You have to ask: how did I let the system make me unrecognizable? How did I let my circumstances corner my spirit? How did I trade the dreams that once kept me alive for metrics that mean nothing? I had to face the truth: I had built a beautiful life around my exhaustion. I had made success out of survival. So, I stopped calling it ambition when it was really avoidance. I stopped calling it resilience when it was really repression. And I stopped calling it leadership when it was really loss. Surrender is what made room for peace. Peace didn‚Äôt come when I achieved more. It came when I decided I didn‚Äôt have to earn my right to rest. That‚Äôs when I began to rebuild ‚Äî not the version of me the system wanted, but the one who could finally breathe. The Spark Returns: Rebuilding a Future-Ready Culture That Breathes When I stopped lying to myself, the light began to return. Slowly, at first ‚Äî like morning through fog. It started with small things: breathing deeper, sitting still, watching the mountain outside my home catch fire at sunset. There‚Äôs a moment each evening when the light hits the ridge, and doves fly across the sky. Every time I see them, I think, there‚Äôs still hope. Because there is. Press enter or click to view image in full size The sunset that makes life worth living ‚Äî proof that light always returns, even after you forget what warmth feels like. I believe we can build systems that make people well. I believe culture can be infrastructure, not performance. I believe organizations can be designed like living organisms ‚Äî breathing, adapting, healing. That‚Äôs what my work is now: to build happy people and happy systems, to make sure the light never leaves anyone‚Äôs eyes again. ‚ÄúLove is patient, love is kind‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî but our systems are neither. They rush and consume. They measure everything except meaning. I don‚Äôt want to just reform work; I want to reimagine it. To teach leaders how to hold truth without collapsing. To show teams how to turn conflict into clarity. To help people remember that their humanity was never the problem. Because when we say ‚Äúfuture of work,‚Äù we can‚Äôt just mean tech and AI and new tools. We have to mean us. How we treat each other. How we tell the truth. How we repair what‚Äôs been broken. The future of work is spiritual work. And I‚Äôm not afraid to say it anymore. The Revolution: Why the Future of Work Is Spiritual Work We are in a global emotional crisis. People are exhausted, disconnected, surviving more than they‚Äôre living. We call it burnout, but it‚Äôs really grief ‚Äî grief for the selves we lost while trying to belong. We‚Äôve built a world that rewards silence, obedience, and performance, and then we wonder why no one feels alive. But I‚Äôve seen the other side. I‚Äôve seen what happens when people tell the truth. When leaders choose accountability over image. When organizations make space for the full complexity of being human. Something shifts. The air changes. People start breathing again. That‚Äôs the revolution I believe in ‚Äî the quiet kind. The kind that starts in meeting rooms, classrooms, kitchens, and mirrors. The kind that starts when one person decides not to pretend anymore. We don‚Äôt need another campaign or corporate slogan. We need a spiritual wake-up call. We need courage, compassion, and new architecture. We need to stop calling the sickness normal. I know what it feels like to lose yourself in the name of success. And I know what it feels like to find yourself again. The spark that left my eyes ‚Äî it came back. And now my work is to help others find theirs. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman in the mountains ‚Äî where the air is clear and the work is spiritual. Because the real revolution is remembering what it means to feel alive. History will remember the builders of systems that breathe ‚Äî the ones who chose repair over performance, the ones who remembered that work was always meant to serve life, not replace it. The spark came back. The question is ‚Äî will you let yours return? Samantha Truman is the Founder of True People Consulting , a culture and strategy firm helping organizations design the future of work ‚Äî not as a performance, but as a living system. She‚Äôs known for her frameworks on cultural health, psychological safety, and future-ready leadership, and her voice at the intersection of equity, spirituality, and systems design. Her mission is simple: to build happy people and happy systems. If this resonated, share it ‚Äî or reach out. Because culture doesn‚Äôt change through slogans. It changes through us. I felt sick. I remember looking in the mirror ‚Äî 190 pounds, heart failing, the spark gone from my eyes. The paychecks were good. The travel, the clothes, the cars, the house ‚Äî all there. But the light was gone. And that was the moment I realized: the problem wasn‚Äôt money. It was the system.","hasDropCap":true,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_3":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_3","name":"f68e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The infrastructure. The way things are built in our workplaces and in our societies. Because when I looked around, I saw sickness everywhere. People smiling while silently dying inside. Burnout. Isolation. Absurd health conditions. Shortened lives. People working themselves into the ground and still struggling to afford a decent meal.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_4":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_4","name":"2dcd","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"You can‚Äôt convince me this is what God had in mind for us. You can‚Äôt tell me a loving God designed a world where joy is a luxury and exhaustion is proof of worth. That‚Äôs when it hit me ‚Äî the system isn‚Äôt broken. It‚Äôs working. It was built to function this way: extractive, performative, and indifferent to the human condition.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*v3EckEro2MFI6XDGmzsxBQ.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*v3EckEro2MFI6XDGmzsxBQ.jpeg","originalHeight":3024,"originalWidth":4032,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_5":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_5","name":"f66b","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*v3EckEro2MFI6XDGmzsxBQ.jpeg"},"text":"The windmills in Pirogovo, Ukraine ‚Äî where the sky is impossibly blue and endlessly wide, a reminder of what still matters when everything else falls away.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_6":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_6","name":"13ba","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And it‚Äôs not just one industry. I‚Äôve worked across them all ‚Äî healthcare, tech, education, corporate. I‚Äôve facilitated to over twenty thousand people, advised executive leaders, sat in rooms where everyone talked about innovation but no one talked about humanity. No matter where I went, the sickness followed. Different offices, same symptoms. Because people are people ‚Äî and when systems are sick, people suffer.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_7":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_7","name":"4874","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I‚Äôve mastered the hustle. I‚Äôve studied it from every angle ‚Äî as the employee, the consultant, the executive, the founder. And the hardest life lesson I‚Äôve learned is this: if you don‚Äôt know where you‚Äôre going, you‚Äôll end up lost ‚Äî sometimes in a corner of your own making.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_8":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_8","name":"cd7d","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I got lost inside achievement. I got lost inside perfection. I got lost inside systems that rewarded my silence and called it professionalism. And when I finally saw how unrecognizable I‚Äôd become, I had to ask myself: how did the system transform me? How did I let it dim my light, drain my spirit, erase my essence ‚Äî and for what? A paycheck? A car? A title?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_9":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_9","name":"2f2a","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"It wasn‚Äôt worth it. Because no matter how far I climbed, I couldn‚Äôt escape the truth: we‚Äôre building lives inside infrastructures that were never built for our well-being. And I refuse to perform wellness for systems that make people sick. I want to build happy people and happy systems. That‚Äôs what my work whispers beneath it all. That‚Äôs the call. Because if you want to see better, you have to be willing to look at the rot. And most people don‚Äôt want to go there. But that‚Äôs where the real work begins.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_10":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_10","name":"bdd0","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The System That Made Me Sick: How Work Lost Its Humanity","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_11":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_11","name":"2a10","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"It didn‚Äôt matter where I went ‚Äî tech, healthcare, corporate, nonprofits ‚Äî the same sickness followed. Different names, same disease. I‚Äôve been in so many organizations, dissected them from the inside, and no matter how fancy the strategy deck, the truth is always the same: people are people, and most systems are sick.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_12":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_12","name":"1c72","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I first realized it when I looked around and noticed how much pain we‚Äôve normalized. This when I realized that we are entering the 2030 Renaissance. Suicide rates high. Burnout everywhere. You can‚Äôt even walk into a supermarket and buy a healthy meal half the time because people are living paycheck to paycheck.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":131,"end":147,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedium.com\u002F@samantha_truman\u002Fthe-workplace-renaissance-why-2030-will-redefine-work-and-leadership-4dd332f3ed77","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*9ldR5_mSEbZCxNC2VwWj8g.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*9ldR5_mSEbZCxNC2VwWj8g.jpeg","originalHeight":4032,"originalWidth":3024,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_13":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_13","name":"5c35","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*9ldR5_mSEbZCxNC2VwWj8g.jpeg"},"text":"Portland, Jamaica ‚Äî the place that taught me the system was never just corporate. It was cultural. Generational. Colonial. And it still shapes how we work today.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_14":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_14","name":"4238","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The system works exactly as it was built to ‚Äî extractive, performative, and indifferent to the soul. It‚Äôs not broken. It was designed this way. And I‚Äôve been in enough rooms to know: most people aren‚Äôt ready to face that truth. Because if they did, they‚Äôd have to change something.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_15":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_15","name":"6a86","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"When I first entered the culture industry and specialized in DEI, I thought I‚Äôd finally found my people. Finally, we were talking about harm, about invisibility, about the weight that underrepresented people carry. I thought, yes, this is the work. But then I started to see the same patterns repeating ‚Äî the same corporate performance, the same fear of real accountability, the same obsession with language and optics while people on the ground were still breaking.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":226,"end":248,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_16":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_16","name":"c4d2","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"You can‚Äôt decorate decay. You have to name it. You have to face it. And when you do, you realize most of our workplaces are just mirrors of society: beautiful from afar, corroded underneath. I‚Äôve sat with executives who talk about ‚Äútransformation‚Äù but refuse to give up control. I‚Äôve seen people say they want change, but not costly change. I‚Äôve watched good people silence themselves because speaking the truth might cost them their position, their reputation, or their peace.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":326,"end":332,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_17":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_17","name":"dee9","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"So no, the problem isn‚Äôt just cultural ‚Äî it‚Äôs spiritual. And that‚Äôs why I do what I do.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_18":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_18","name":"d71f","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Survival: Living Through the Workplace Burnout Epidemic","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_19":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_19","name":"9d2a","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Before I built systems, I survived them. I was born in Ukraine to a Ukrainian mother and a Jamaican father. Then moved to Jamaica with a professional tyrant for a father ‚Äî cunning, volatile, and cruel. My childhood was a masterclass in adaptation. I learned early that survival meant reading the room, staying quiet, moving strategically.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_20":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_20","name":"39f4","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Eventually, I made it to California at fourteen with my mother and Palestinian stepfather ‚Äî silenced, shape-shifting to fit the world around me. I buried my accent for safety. Wore the same clothes week after week. Tried to pass. Tried to belong. Tried to disappear just enough to survive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_21":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_21","name":"53d1","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I had grit. That was never the problem. It‚Äôs what kept me alive. By sixteen, I shaved my head. I needed a purge. By seventeen, I was homeless. And still, I fought. Because even then, I could imagine a future better than the one I was living","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_22":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_22","name":"11bf","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I became a filmmaker. Then a shopping host on cruise ships. A flight attendant. A consultant. A corporate leader. Now, a founder. I‚Äôve lived in every layer of the hierarchy ‚Äî from paycheck-to-paycheck employee to executive insider. And what I learned at every level is this: the sickness doesn‚Äôt discriminate. It just changes clothes.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*MHoPMjx_Wnn_g2ca4VkYrg.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*MHoPMjx_Wnn_g2ca4VkYrg.jpeg","originalHeight":1707,"originalWidth":4096,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_23":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_23","name":"3dcc","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*MHoPMjx_Wnn_g2ca4VkYrg.jpeg"},"text":"Samantha Truman, producing her first feature film at 18. Before the deadlines, the deliverables, the exhaustion ‚Äî before the spark began to slip away.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_24":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_24","name":"9611","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I‚Äôve seen it in blue-collar workers afraid to call in sick. In executives terrified to be seen as human. In young people confusing busyness with purpose. In elders counting down to retirement like it‚Äôs salvation. I‚Äôve lived it too ‚Äî the performing, the over-giving, the disappearing. The slow erasure of self in systems that call it ambition.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_25":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_25","name":"8a63","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And then one day, my body rebelled. Heart failure. Ten years of undiagnosed hypertension. My body had been whispering for years, but I was too busy proving myself to listen. When it finally screamed, I had to. That‚Äôs when I realized: the system isn‚Äôt only outside of us ‚Äî it‚Äôs inside of us. It‚Äôs the voices that say ‚Äúwork harder.‚Äù It‚Äôs the fear that if you slow down, you‚Äôll lose your worth. It‚Äôs the conditioning that tells you to hide the parts that don‚Äôt look like power.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_26":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_26","name":"5da3","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"So I stopped. I stopped performing survival. I stopped making myself smaller for systems that couldn‚Äôt hold me. I stopped calling sickness ‚Äúsuccess.‚Äù And I made a decision: if the world was going to keep building systems that break people, I‚Äôd spend the rest of my life building systems that breathe. Because I‚Äôve lived what happens when we don‚Äôt. I‚Äôve been the girl who had nothing. The woman who had everything. And the human who realized that both are empty if you‚Äôve lost your soul in the process.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_27":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_27","name":"a678","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Surrender: Redefining Success, Rest, and Human-Centered Leadership","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_28":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_28","name":"00cb","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"At some point, the fight has to stop. Not because you‚Äôve lost ‚Äî but because you‚Äôve finally realized you don‚Äôt have to fight yourself to live. In 2025, I walked away from an executive role to focus on building for the future. Not someone else‚Äôs future ‚Äî mine. Humanity‚Äôs. For the first time, I stopped running long enough to look in the mirror and really see.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_29":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_29","name":"6a06","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I did an exercise I now call ‚Äúthe good, the bad, and the ugly.‚Äù The ‚Äúugly‚Äù section was so long it scared me. It was a mirror I couldn‚Äôt look away from. Every mistake, every betrayal, every way I‚Äôd silenced myself, every version of me that had learned to perform strength because no one ever taught her safety.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_30":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_30","name":"06c0","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And instead of editing it, I faced it. That version of me ‚Äî the one who could finally look at everything ‚Äî surrendered. Not to defeat, but to truth. Because sometimes the ugliest parts of you are the ones that most need your compassion. You don‚Äôt heal by hiding what happened. You heal by accepting it, naming it, and releasing the shame attached to it.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg","originalHeight":3024,"originalWidth":4032,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_31":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_31","name":"08b4","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg"},"text":"Lisbon, Portugal ‚Äî Samantha Truman with her then-toddler. Another beautiful escape that couldn‚Äôt fix what she refused to face.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_32":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_32","name":"0115","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"That‚Äôs what surrender was for me ‚Äî the choice to stop running from myself. It didn‚Äôt mean smiling through it. It meant standing in the middle of it and saying, yes, this happened. And it‚Äôs not all of who I am. Because when the spark leaves your eyes, you have to fight to get it back. And the first fight isn‚Äôt with the world ‚Äî it‚Äôs with yourself.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_33":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_33","name":"3adc","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"You have to ask: how did I let the system make me unrecognizable? How did I let my circumstances corner my spirit? How did I trade the dreams that once kept me alive for metrics that mean nothing? I had to face the truth: I had built a beautiful life around my exhaustion. I had made success out of survival. So, I stopped calling it ambition when it was really avoidance. I stopped calling it resilience when it was really repression. And I stopped calling it leadership when it was really loss.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_34":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_34","name":"5f7d","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Surrender is what made room for peace. Peace didn‚Äôt come when I achieved more. It came when I decided I didn‚Äôt have to earn my right to rest. That‚Äôs when I began to rebuild ‚Äî not the version of me the system wanted, but the one who could finally breathe.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_35":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_35","name":"1eff","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Spark Returns: Rebuilding a Future-Ready Culture That Breathes","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_36":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_36","name":"4f71","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"When I stopped lying to myself, the light began to return. Slowly, at first ‚Äî like morning through fog. It started with small things: breathing deeper, sitting still, watching the mountain outside my home catch fire at sunset. There‚Äôs a moment each evening when the light hits the ridge, and doves fly across the sky. Every time I see them, I think, there‚Äôs still hope. Because there is.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":350,"end":369,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg","originalHeight":1611,"originalWidth":3024,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_37":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_37","name":"2da9","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg"},"text":"The sunset that makes life worth living ‚Äî proof that light always returns, even after you forget what warmth feels like.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_38":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_38","name":"30dd","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I believe we can build systems that make people well. I believe culture can be infrastructure, not performance. I believe organizations can be designed like living organisms ‚Äî breathing, adapting, healing. That‚Äôs what my work is now: to build happy people and happy systems, to make sure the light never leaves anyone‚Äôs eyes again.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_39":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_39","name":"eb08","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"‚ÄúLove is patient, love is kind‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî but our systems are neither. They rush and consume. They measure everything except meaning. I don‚Äôt want to just reform work; I want to reimagine it. To teach leaders how to hold truth without collapsing. To show teams how to turn conflict into clarity. To help people remember that their humanity was never the problem.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_40":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_40","name":"1db2","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Because when we say ‚Äúfuture of work,‚Äù we can‚Äôt just mean tech and AI and new tools. We have to mean us. How we treat each other. How we tell the truth. How we repair what‚Äôs been broken. The future of work is spiritual work. And I‚Äôm not afraid to say it anymore.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":100,"end":103,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_41":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_41","name":"a3bd","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Revolution: Why the Future of Work Is Spiritual Work","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_42":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_42","name":"5f73","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"We are in a global emotional crisis. People are exhausted, disconnected, surviving more than they‚Äôre living. We call it burnout, but it‚Äôs really grief ‚Äî grief for the selves we lost while trying to belong. We‚Äôve built a world that rewards silence, obedience, and performance, and then we wonder why no one feels alive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_43":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_43","name":"0625","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"But I‚Äôve seen the other side. I‚Äôve seen what happens when people tell the truth. When leaders choose accountability over image. When organizations make space for the full complexity of being human. Something shifts. The air changes. People start breathing again.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_44":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_44","name":"5b4f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"That‚Äôs the revolution I believe in ‚Äî the quiet kind. The kind that starts in meeting rooms, classrooms, kitchens, and mirrors. The kind that starts when one person decides not to pretend anymore. We don‚Äôt need another campaign or corporate slogan. We need a spiritual wake-up call. We need courage, compassion, and new architecture. We need to stop calling the sickness normal.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_45":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_45","name":"b52e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I know what it feels like to lose yourself in the name of success. And I know what it feels like to find yourself again. The spark that left my eyes ‚Äî it came back. And now my work is to help others find theirs.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg","originalHeight":4032,"originalWidth":3024,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_46":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_46","name":"1367","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg"},"text":"Samantha Truman in the mountains ‚Äî where the air is clear and the work is spiritual. Because the real revolution is remembering what it means to feel alive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_47":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_47","name":"1737","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"History will remember the builders of systems that breathe ‚Äî the ones who chose repair over performance, the ones who remembered that work was always meant to serve life, not replace it. The spark came back. key_insights: Burnout is a systemic issue, not an individual failure - workplace infrastructures are designed in ways that harm employee wellbeing
The problem transcends industries - healthcare, tech, education, and corporate sectors all exhibit similar patterns of employee exhaustion and disconnection
True organizational transformation requires spiritual and cultural work, not just policy changes or wellness programs
Performance-based workplace cultures reward silence and conformity while eroding human authenticity and health
Building 'systems that breathe' requires leaders to prioritize human-centered design, psychological safety, and genuine accountability
The future of work must address the emotional and spiritual dimensions of human experience, not just technological advancement
Personal surrender and self-reflection are necessary precursors to building healthier organizational systems
Cultural health should be treated as infrastructure, not performance or optics
summary: A deeply personal account from cultural strategist Samantha Truman about her journey through severe burnout and what it revealed about systemic workplace dysfunction. The essay chronicles her experience across multiple industries, her physical and emotional collapse (heart failure, 190 pounds, loss of vitality), and her realization that workplace systems are designed to extract rather than sustain human wellbeing. Truman argues that burnout is not an individual problem but a structural one, calling for a fundamental reimagining of work culture that prioritizes human-centered systems, psychological safety, and spiritual health. She advocates for building 'systems that breathe' and positions the future of work as fundamentally spiritual work.

Why Leaders Miss the $8.8 Trillion Problem Hiding in Their Culture Workplace culture failures cost $8.8T globally. Leaders miss it because they focus on metrics, not the invisible architecture of work. Samantha Truman Sep 19, 2025 1 Share The Invisible Architecture of Work: Seeing What Leaders Miss When we talk about culture, most people think about surface-level things: team lunches, a values poster, the annual retreat. But culture isn‚Äôt what‚Äôs written on the wall. It‚Äôs the invisible architecture underneath‚Äîthe unspoken agreements, the quiet fears, the subtle signals that shape how people actually move through the system. And here‚Äôs the hard truth: leaders often miss it. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Subscribe They‚Äôre looking at dashboards. They‚Äôre looking at strategy decks. They‚Äôre listening to a few loud voices in the room. But they‚Äôre not paying attention to what lives beneath‚Äîthe human system where work and real life collide. I‚Äôve seen it over and over: the immigrant employee navigating systemic bias at work with the same exhaustion she carries outside; the new manager who feels like a survivalist rather than a leader because the ‚Äúempowerment‚Äù promised on paper isn‚Äôt matched by trust in practice; the high-potential Black woman who never speaks in executive meetings‚Äînot because she lacks confidence, but because she‚Äôs calculated that the risk outweighs the reward. This is what I call the invisible architecture. It‚Äôs the weight of inequity, power, and unspoken rules that employees carry into every interaction. It‚Äôs not about perks. It‚Äôs about survival. The Economic Cost of Ignoring Culture And the cost of ignoring this system is massive. Gallup found that only 32% of U.S. employees are engaged, while 51% are ‚Äúnot engaged‚Äù and 13% are ‚Äúactively disengaged.‚Äù That means two-thirds of your workforce is essentially checked out . The economic cost? $8.8 trillion globally‚Äîabout 9% of world GDP . That‚Äôs not just a people issue. That‚Äôs your bottom line bleeding. When leaders ask me why their strategy isn‚Äôt sticking, or why turnover is spiking, or why performance feels flat despite strong hiring, the answer usually isn‚Äôt in the strategy at all. It‚Äôs in the invisible architecture. Share The Culture Room Questions Leaders Aren‚Äôt Asking The problem is, you can‚Äôt see it if you‚Äôre only looking at quarterly reports or sanitized employee surveys. You have to get underneath. You have to ask the harder questions: What are the unspoken rules in this system? Where do people feel silenced, unsafe, or unseen? What cultural ‚Äútaxes‚Äù are women, people of color, caregivers, or immigrants paying just to survive the day? How do our systems unintentionally reward silence and punish truth? Leaders who can‚Äôt‚Äîor won‚Äôt‚Äîsee this architecture will always misdiagnose their problems. They‚Äôll double down on perks, restructure, swap executives, or launch new initiatives, while the root cause goes untouched. What Brave Leaders See But leaders who do see it‚Äîwho are willing to face the invisible architecture‚Äîunlock something rare. They build cultures that breathe. Cultures where people don‚Äôt just endure the system, they shape it. That‚Äôs the real work of cultural strategy. Not slogans. Not ‚Äúresilience workshops.‚Äù But reshaping the architecture itself so people don‚Äôt have to contort themselves just to belong. Because culture isn‚Äôt just about what happens at work. It‚Äôs about whether people can bring their full humanity to the table‚Äîand whether leaders are brave enough to see what they‚Äôve been missing. If you‚Äôre a leader who‚Äôs ready to look beyond dashboards and face the invisible architecture of your culture, subscribe for more essays‚Äîor connect with me on LinkedIn . The cost of silence is too high to ignore. Message Samantha Truman Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Leaders miss it because they focus on metrics, not the invisible architecture of work.\",\"body_html\":\" The Invisible Architecture of Work: Seeing What Leaders Miss When we talk about culture, most people think about surface-level things: team lunches, a values poster, the annual retreat. But culture isn\u2019t what\u2019s written on the wall. It\u2019s the invisible architecture underneath\u2014the unspoken agreements, the quiet fears, the subtle signals that shape how people actually move through the system. And here\u2019s the hard truth: leaders often miss it. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. They\u2019re looking at dashboards. They\u2019re looking at strategy decks. They\u2019re listening to a few loud voices in the room. But they\u2019re not paying attention to what lives beneath\u2014the human system where work and real life collide. I\u2019ve seen it over and over: the immigrant employee navigating systemic bias at work with the same exhaustion she carries outside; the new manager who feels like a survivalist rather than a leader because the \u201Cempowerment\u201D promised on paper isn\u2019t matched by trust in practice; the high-potential Black woman who never speaks in executive meetings\u2014not because she lacks confidence, but because she\u2019s calculated that the risk outweighs the reward. This is what I call the invisible architecture. It\u2019s the weight of inequity, power, and unspoken rules that employees carry into every interaction. It\u2019s not about perks. It\u2019s about survival. The Economic Cost of Ignoring Culture And the cost of ignoring this system is massive. Gallup found that only 32% of U.S. employees are engaged, while 51% are \u201Cnot engaged\u201D and 13% are \u201Cactively disengaged.\u201D That means two-thirds of your workforce is essentially checked out . The economic cost? $8.8 trillion globally\u2014about 9% of world GDP . That\u2019s not just a people issue. That\u2019s your bottom line bleeding. When leaders ask me why their strategy isn\u2019t sticking, or why turnover is spiking, or why performance feels flat despite strong hiring, the answer usually isn\u2019t in the strategy at all. It\u2019s in the invisible architecture. Share The Culture Room Questions Leaders Aren\u2019t Asking The problem is, you can\u2019t see it if you\u2019re only looking at quarterly reports or sanitized employee surveys. You have to get underneath. You have to ask the harder questions: What are the unspoken rules in this system? Where do people feel silenced, unsafe, or unseen? What cultural \u201Ctaxes\u201D are women, people of color, caregivers, or immigrants paying just to survive the day? How do our systems unintentionally reward silence and punish truth? Leaders who can\u2019t\u2014or won\u2019t\u2014see this architecture will always misdiagnose their problems. They\u2019ll double down on perks, restructure, swap executives, or launch new initiatives, while the root cause goes untouched. What Brave Leaders See But leaders who do see it\u2014who are willing to face the invisible architecture\u2014unlock something rare. They build cultures that breathe. Cultures where people don\u2019t just endure the system, they shape it. That\u2019s the real work of cultural strategy. Not slogans. Not \u201Cresilience workshops.\u201D But reshaping the architecture itself so people don\u2019t have to contort themselves just to belong. Because culture isn\u2019t just about what happens at work. It\u2019s about whether people can bring their full humanity to the table\u2014and whether leaders are brave enough to see what they\u2019ve been missing. If you\u2019re a leader who\u2019s ready to look beyond dashboards and face the invisible architecture of your culture, subscribe for more essays\u2014or connect with me on LinkedIn . The cost of silence is too high to ignore. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! key_insights: Workplace culture failures cost $8.8 trillion globally, representing 9% of world GDP
Only 32% of U.S. employees are engaged, with two-thirds essentially checked out
Leaders often miss the 'invisible architecture' of culture - unspoken rules, power dynamics, and systemic inequities
Culture isn't about perks or values posters - it's about the human systems where work and real life collide
Cultural 'taxes' disproportionately affect women, people of color, caregivers, and immigrants
Leaders focus on dashboards and metrics while missing the underlying cultural dynamics affecting performance
Effective cultural strategy requires reshaping the architecture itself, not just implementing surface-level initiatives
summary: This article examines why leaders fail to recognize the massive economic impact of workplace culture failures ($8.8T globally). Author Samantha Truman introduces the concept of 'invisible architecture' - the unspoken rules, power dynamics, and systemic inequities that shape employee experiences but remain hidden from traditional metrics. The piece argues that leaders miss these critical cultural elements by focusing on dashboards rather than the human systems underneath, resulting in widespread disengagement and performance issues. It calls for brave leadership that addresses root cultural causes rather than surface-level solutions.

Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon The Culture Industry Has a Credibility Problem: What the Deloitte Scandal Reveals About How We Consult Culture (and Why It Can‚Äôt Be Just Performance) Samantha Truman 5 min read ¬∑ 6 days ago -- Listen Share W hen I first read about the Deloitte report scandal, I wasn‚Äôt shocked. I remembered a conversation from a job interview I had with Deloitte a few years ago. I asked the recruiter about their structure, and she told me that consultants‚Äô laptop activity was monitored. She also mentioned, almost casually, that it wasn‚Äôt unusual for consultants to work sixty hours a week. I don‚Äôt balk at hard work; but I require integrity in what I invest my time toward. The cultural cues in that conversation were loud: control, surveillance, relentless output. I declined to move forward on the call. Based on that conversation and the cultural cues I picked up, I realized their lifestyle wasn‚Äôt for me. The pace wasn‚Äôt the problem; the posture was. Press enter or click to view image in full size Now, seeing that Deloitte delivered a AUD $440,000 report to an Australian government agency riddled with AI hallucinations and fabricated citations, I am not surprised. That kind of foundational crack is rarely sudden. It reflects a culture that deprioritized care, accountability, and rigorous truth in favor of velocity and performance. The Guardian reported that Deloitte agreed to refund part of the fee after discovering that sections of the report included invented references. ABC News confirmed that Deloitte partially refunded the payment after the Department of Industry and Science raised concerns about accuracy. The Australian Financial Review later published Deloitte‚Äôs apology, quoting the firm‚Äôs statement that ‚Äúoversight was not followed.‚Äù Even after the revision, journalists found more errors and ‚Äúirrelevant citations.‚Äù That‚Äôs not a technical glitch ‚Äî that‚Äôs a cultural failure. When Culture Becomes the Weakest Link When a company‚Äôs focus is anchored solely on ROI and KPI, culture quietly slips through the cracks. You see it everywhere: metrics without meaning, speed without scrutiny, and work that is measured in volume instead of value. In Deloitte‚Äôs case, the report was meant to inform public strategy ‚Äî to help a government make decisions for its people. And yet, somehow, an internal culture that prized speed and volume over integrity allowed shortcuts to pass as substance. When leaders create a culture that glorifies output at all costs, truth becomes negotiable. If you don‚Äôt take pride in the work that informs policy and public trust, what do you take pride in? It‚Äôs possible this failure wasn‚Äôt systemic across Deloitte. It could have been one team, one region, one oversight. But the question worth asking is: Why did this happen even once? What systems of accountability allowed it to? And more importantly, what kind of cultural environment makes professionals so rushed, so pressured, or so desensitized that integrity slips by unnoticed? Psychological Safety Isn‚Äôt Just a Buzzword In theory, consulting firms talk about ‚Äúpsychological safety.‚Äù In practice, it‚Äôs often the first casualty of a deadline. When people feel they can‚Äôt question authority or push back against unrealistic timelines, that‚Äôs not psychological safety ; that‚Äôs quiet compliance. Let‚Äôs imagine a hypothetical moment: A junior analyst raises a concern, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find a source for this citation. Should we leave it out?‚Äù A manager replies, ‚ÄúJust keep it moving. We‚Äôre already late.‚Äù That moment, the instant when someone chooses convenience over correctness , is where culture reveals itself. It‚Äôs not malice. It‚Äôs momentum. And when momentum outruns integrity, failure becomes inevitable. When Values Become Performance I‚Äôve watched consulting firms betray the very values they sell. Many of them are sincere people trapped in systems optimized for optics. ‚ÄúIntegrity‚Äù becomes a brand attribute, not a behavior. ‚ÄúAccountability‚Äù becomes a slide deck, not a standard. I‚Äôve met leaders who couldn‚Äôt recite their company‚Äôs mission but could tell you last quarter‚Äôs numbers to the decimal. When output eclipses origin , culture becomes an empty promise. For years, organizations have treated culture as a marketing differentiator, not a moral compass. But culture isn‚Äôt a campaign; it‚Äôs an infrastructure. It‚Äôs the set of invisible systems that make truth either safe or expensive. The Workplace Renaissance We are in what I call a Workplace Renaissance ‚Äî a collective awakening. People are realizing that the infrastructures we built decades ago are no longer good enough. The cracks we see in institutions, from government to consulting to tech, aren‚Äôt random. They‚Äôre revealing what happens when speed, scale, and status become more sacred than substance. A future-ready culture isn‚Äôt about innovation alone. It‚Äôs about ethical architecture, building organizations on a human foundation, where accountability is not punishment but practice. People spend most of their waking hours at work. If we can fix culture there, the systems of communication, care, and clarity. We can ripple that repair across entire societies. The Five Things Leaders Must Do Next Start with cultural infrastructure, not slogans. Culture isn‚Äôt a set of values painted on walls; it‚Äôs the operating system that runs your decisions. Audit your systems, not just your sentiment. Make integrity a measurable deliverable. Require every team to embed verification processes, transparent sourcing, and explicit AI disclosure. Treat accuracy as a KPI. Empower psychological safety with clarity, not comfort. People should be able to flag risk without fear, but also know exactly how to escalate. Safety doesn‚Äôt mean endless discussion; it means clear permission to speak the truth. Adopt micro-data and micro-learning loops. Replace quarterly retrospectives with short, frequent check-ins. Measure behavior in small doses ‚Äî what worked this week, what broke, what needs recalibration. Work with firms that have a conscience, not just credentials. If you‚Äôre outsourcing culture, hire consultants who live the principles they preach. Ask them: how do you handle mistakes? How do you ensure integrity internally? How do you hold yourselves accountable? A Call to Reckoning Just because you‚Äôre a household name doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre exempt from responsibility. In fact, legacy firms should be the gold standard for accountability. And yet, here we are ‚Äî governments refunding contracts, employees burning out, and the public losing faith in the very institutions designed to guide them. So before you hire the next big name, ask yourself: 1. Do you actually get what you think you‚Äôre paying for? 2. Do you see transformation, or just templates? 3. Are your consultants changing your system ‚Äî or performing inside it? Because culture, at its core, is not what you say you believe. It‚Äôs what you‚Äôre willing to hold accountable when no one‚Äôs watching. If you liked this article, share it with someone shaping the future of work. True People Consulting helps organizations build breathable, high-performing systems that align people, purpose, and practice. We believe in systems that don‚Äôt just perform ‚Äî they live. Follow me on LinkedIn for practical insights, and on Substack for deeper essays. Don‚Äôt just watch history ‚Äî help write it. key_insights: The Deloitte AI hallucination scandal (AUD $440,000 report with fabricated citations) reveals systemic cultural failures, not just technical errors
Culture failures occur when organizations prioritize velocity and performance metrics over integrity and accountability
Psychological safety becomes 'quiet compliance' when people cannot question authority or push back against unrealistic timelines
Corporate values often become performance theater rather than behavioral standards - 'integrity' as brand attribute vs. actual behavior
Organizations need cultural infrastructure, not slogans - culture is the operating system that runs decisions
The 'Workplace Renaissance' represents a collective awakening that legacy organizational infrastructures are inadequate
Five critical actions: build cultural infrastructure, make integrity measurable, empower psychological safety with clarity, adopt micro-learning loops, hire consultants with conscience
When output eclipses origin and momentum outruns integrity, organizational failure becomes inevitable
Legacy firms should be gold standards for accountability, yet often fail when speed and volume override truth
summary: This Medium article analyzes the Deloitte scandal involving a $440,000 Australian government report containing AI-generated hallucinations and fabricated citations. The author, drawing from personal experience interviewing with Deloitte, argues this failure reflects deeper cultural problems in the consulting industry where performance metrics, surveillance, and output volume override integrity and accountability. The piece critiques how organizations treat culture as marketing rather than infrastructure, and calls for a 'Workplace Renaissance' with five specific leadership actions: building cultural infrastructure, making integrity measurable, empowering psychological safety, adopting micro-learning loops, and selecting consultants based on conscience rather than credentials. The article positions this scandal as symptomatic of broader systemic issues where speed and scale become more valued than substance and truth.

The 5 Pillars of Cultural Health Every Leader Needs to Build a Thriving Workplace From clarity to accountability, these five pillars form the invisible architecture that drives trust, performance, and lasting change. Samantha Truman Sep 18, 2025 Share Most organizations treat culture like an afterthought‚Äîsomething you fix with perks, slogans, or an offsite. But culture isn‚Äôt a side project. It‚Äôs the system that determines whether strategy sticks, people thrive, and performance endures. Photo by ian dooley on Unsplash Through my work, I‚Äôve seen the same pattern again and again: companies may dabble in one or two aspects of cultural health, but very few invest in all five. That‚Äôs why change feels impossible to sustain. So what does true cultural health require? 1. Strategic Clarity & Alignment The organization holds a shared, concrete picture of where it‚Äôs going. People can trace their day-to-day work to strategy, KPIs, and outcomes‚Äîso priorities and trade-offs are explicit. Without this alignment, employees spend their days guessing, projects sprawl, and leaders confuse busyness with progress. 2. Cohesion & Psychological Safety Communication is consistent, candid, and respectful across teams. People are supported and can speak up, take risks, and show up as themselves without fear of blame or exclusion. When psychological safety collapses, innovation collapses with it. Silence and fear become the real culture. 3. Technology Experience & Empowerment Tools and systems are accessible, equitable, and matched to how this culture actually works. They remove friction and empower people to do their best work with confidence. The best tech isn‚Äôt the flashiest‚Äîit‚Äôs the one that integrates seamlessly into the way people actually collaborate. 4. Change Agility & Leadership Enablement The organization adapts quickly and learns out loud. Leaders create trust, clarity, and capacity during uncertainty‚Äîequipping people to navigate change rather than endure it. Resilience doesn‚Äôt come from slogans. It comes from leaders modeling vulnerability and courage when the ground shifts. 5. Accountability & Performance Integrity Expectations are clear, commitments are kept, and feedback is timely. Performance conversations and recognition are fair, consistent, and aligned to values and results. Accountability without integrity breeds fear. Integrity without accountability breeds drift. Healthy cultures hold both, tightly. Why It Matters Cultural health isn‚Äôt optional. It‚Äôs the infrastructure that holds strategy, performance, and trust together. Companies that only invest in one or two pillars may see short-term wins‚Äîbut the system eventually buckles. The organizations that will thrive into 2030 are those that see cultural health as strategy, not decoration. üëâ This article is part of my ongoing series on cultural health and the future of work. If you want more essays, frameworks, and stories from inside the culture shift, please subscribe. Or connect with me on LinkedIn to keep the conversation going. clarity to accountability, these five pillars form the invisible architecture that drives trust, performance, and lasting change.\",\"body_html\":\" Most organizations treat culture like an afterthought\u2014something you fix with perks, slogans, or an offsite. But culture isn\u2019t a side project. It\u2019s the system that determines whether strategy sticks, people thrive, and performance endures. Photo by ian dooley on Unsplash Through my work, I\u2019ve seen the same pattern again and again: companies may dabble in one or two aspects of cultural health, but very few invest in all five. That\u2019s why change feels impossible to sustain. So what does true cultural health require? 1. Strategic Clarity & Alignment The organization holds a shared, concrete picture of where it\u2019s going. People can trace their day-to-day work to strategy, KPIs, and outcomes\u2014so priorities and trade-offs are explicit. Without this alignment, employees spend their days guessing, projects sprawl, and leaders confuse busyness with progress. 2. Cohesion & Psychological Safety Communication is consistent, candid, and respectful across teams. People are supported and can speak up, take risks, and show up as themselves without fear of blame or exclusion. When psychological safety collapses, innovation collapses with it. Silence and fear become the real culture. 3. Technology Experience & Empowerment Tools and systems are accessible, equitable, and matched to how this culture actually works. They remove friction and empower people to do their best work with confidence. The best tech isn\u2019t the flashiest\u2014it\u2019s the one that integrates seamlessly into the way people actually collaborate. 4. Change Agility & Leadership Enablement The organization adapts quickly and learns out loud. Leaders create trust, clarity, and capacity during uncertainty\u2014equipping people to navigate change rather than endure it. Resilience doesn\u2019t come from slogans. It comes from leaders modeling vulnerability and courage when the ground shifts. 5. Accountability & Performance Integrity Expectations are clear, commitments are kept, and feedback is timely. Performance conversations and recognition are fair, consistent, and aligned to values and results. Accountability without integrity breeds fear. Integrity without accountability breeds drift. Healthy cultures hold both, tightly. Why It Matters Cultural health isn\u2019t optional. It\u2019s the infrastructure that holds strategy, performance, and trust together. Companies that only invest in one or two pillars may see short-term wins\u2014but the system eventually buckles. The organizations that will thrive into 2030 are those that see cultural health as strategy, not decoration. \uD83D\uDC49 This article is part of my ongoing series on cultural health and the future of work. If you want more essays, frameworks, and stories from inside the culture shift, please subscribe. key_insights: Cultural health requires investment in five interconnected pillars, not just one or two isolated initiatives
Strategic clarity and alignment enable employees to connect daily work to organizational outcomes and make explicit trade-offs
Psychological safety is foundational to innovation - when it collapses, silence and fear become the dominant culture
Technology should integrate seamlessly into actual work patterns rather than being the flashiest option
Leadership resilience comes from modeling vulnerability and courage during uncertainty, not from slogans
Accountability and integrity must coexist - accountability without integrity breeds fear, integrity without accountability breeds drift
Cultural health is infrastructure, not decoration - it holds strategy, performance, and trust together
Organizations that will thrive into 2030 treat cultural health as strategy, not an afterthought
summary: This article presents a framework for building organizational cultural health through five essential pillars: Strategic Clarity & Alignment, Cohesion & Psychological Safety, Technology Experience & Empowerment, Change Agility & Leadership Enablement, and Accountability & Performance Integrity. The author argues that most organizations fail to sustain cultural change because they invest in only one or two pillars rather than all five. The piece emphasizes that cultural health is not optional decoration but critical infrastructure that determines whether strategy succeeds, people thrive, and performance endures.
