Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon Politics of Health Equity: The Price of Silence Samantha Truman 5 min read ¬∑ Jun 6, 2025 -- Listen Share By Samantha Truman Right now, millions are being dropped from Medicaid rolls. Food insecurity is rising, leaving families without consistent access to fresh, nutritious meals. Community hospitals are closing, severing vital lifelines in already underserved regions. Yet some still politicize equity, treating it as a threat rather than the foundation of a just healthcare system. But to me, health equity isn‚Äôt political. It‚Äôs personal. A Tale of a Few Cities Before I was a healthcare leader, I was a 19-year-old trying to survive in a system never designed for people like me. Born in Ukraine, raised in Jamaica, and shaped by a stepfather from Palestine, my life gave me a deeply global and intersectional perspective on health and justice. Each place revealed how identity, politics, and history decide who gets care ‚Äî and who doesn‚Äôt. Press enter or click to view image in full size In Ukraine, I was born into a post-Soviet health system marked by scarcity, where underfunded institutions struggled to meet basic needs. In Jamaica, I witnessed how colonial legacies and chronic underinvestment led to shortages and a brain drain as healthcare workers left seeking stability. Through my stepfather‚Äôs Palestinian heritage, I learned health is not just clinical care ‚Äî it is a human right, one threatened daily by occupation, displacement, and systemic violence. These experiences root my commitment to health equity as a global imperative ‚Äî one demanding structural change and deep cultural humility. From Survival to Awareness As a teenager, my family moved to California, where my immigrant parents ‚Äî skilled professionals abroad ‚Äî struggled to find work that reflected their expertise. From 14, I saw how hard it was to start over in a system that didn‚Äôt recognize our worth. We were poor. My parents were often sick. It fell to me to find a way forward. At 19, I landed a job at a multinational logistics company earning $12.50 an hour, just 50 cents more than my previous banking job. That small raise allowed me to leave a friend‚Äôs couch in San Bernardino and rent a cramped 200-square-foot studio in Chula Vista, a working-class border community. From my door, I could see the Mexican flag waving in the wind. Some nights, staring at it, I‚Äôd wonder what happens next. By day, I worked in La Jolla ‚Äî an upscale enclave with boutique cafes, luxury cars, and oceanfront mansions. People there moved differently. They smiled more, lived longer, bought fresh food without a second thought. Back in Chula Vista, I rationed food and gas. I survived mostly on baked potatoes, sometimes with butter and cheese if I was lucky. I breathed in pollution, battled roaches, and pushed through fatigue. At 19, I didn‚Äôt understand why I felt so worn down. Now, I know: I was living the embodied toll of inequality. The Physical Toll of Inequality Pelvic pain from heavy lifting turned into a hairline fracture, then a full one. Signs of hypertension were missed for years, eventually leading to heart issues. These weren‚Äôt isolated health events ‚Äî they were consequences of working-class precarity, food insecurity, and stress. Whenever I walked through La Jolla or visited a Whole Foods, I felt a sharp contrast. Their health was supported by environment and access. Mine was deteriorating from deprivation. I didn‚Äôt know about social programs that could‚Äôve helped. I wasn‚Äôt aware of how deeply the places we live, work, and grow shape our health. If I could go back, I‚Äôd want that knowledge early ‚Äî because education could‚Äôve made my path easier. The Cost of Inequality ‚Äî Locally and Globally What I experienced was more than poverty. It was a textbook example of how social determinants of health shape up to 80% of health outcomes, according to the CDC. And this reality is not confined to the U.S. In Jamaica , underfunded systems, medical shortages, and climate change strain already fragile infrastructure. In Ukraine , just before the 2022 invasion, my parents received exceptional post-operative care. But war has turned healthcare into a humanitarian crisis ‚Äî interrupting treatments, displacing providers, and making care increasingly unaffordable. My grandmother, living on a $50 monthly pension, now faces soaring medical costs she cannot pay. In Gaza , the health system is collapsing under siege. Hospitals have been bombed, doctors killed, and access to food, water, and care deliberately blocked. There is no neutrality in the destruction of healthcare. In all these places, injustice, violence, and economic constraint deepen inequities. These are not isolated crises. They are global echoes of systemic failure. Closer to home, in California, Chula Vista had been redlined for decades, starved of investment. It remains a food desert, with poor housing and limited care. Just 20 miles away, La Jolla flourishes. The difference between these zip codes isn‚Äôt just income ‚Äî it‚Äôs life expectancy. In California, people in wealthier neighborhoods live 10 to 15 years longer than those in historically disinvested ones. Equity Is Not Up for Debate Despite overwhelming evidence, health equity faces fierce political attack. What was once a moral and public health imperative is now dismissed as divisive. But acknowledging the disproportionate harm faced by marginalized communities isn‚Äôt controversial ‚Äî it‚Äôs responsible. Research shows that chronic exposure to racism, poverty, and instability ‚Äî what scholars call ‚Äúweathering‚Äù ‚Äî leads to early chronic illness, higher hypertension, and increased maternal mortality. Yet across the country, there are efforts to erase these truths. Public health agencies are pressured to remove ‚Äúequity‚Äù from strategic plans. DEI programs are being dismantled. Some states have banned DEI language entirely. Over 20 million people risk losing Medicaid coverage due to rollbacks ‚Äî harming Black, Brown, and low-income communities most. And Black women remain three times more likely than white women to die from pregnancy-related causes, regardless of income or education. These are not abstract debates. They are life-and-death decisions about who is seen, who is cared for, and who survives. The Foundation of a Just Healthcare System Health equity is not charity. It‚Äôs not a luxury. It‚Äôs the foundation of a functioning healthcare system. When everyone has access to preventive care, fresh food, clean air, and stable housing, society benefits. Life expectancy improves. Productivity rises. Healthcare costs fall. Solutions exist: ‚Äì Expand Medicaid access ‚Äì Invest in culturally competent care ‚Äì Reverse redlining through community development ‚Äì Protect DEI initiatives in health institutions These are practical, evidence-based steps toward fairness. The Urgency of Now The question isn‚Äôt whether health equity matters. It‚Äôs whether we have the courage to fight for it. Will we listen to communities in crisis? Will we protect policies that guarantee fair access to care? I know the road ahead will be hard. But I also know this: I will not be silent . To every policymaker, healthcare leader, advocate, and organizer: I invite you to stand with me. Because until every person, in every country, can live a healthy life, our work is far from over. Food insecurity is rising, leaving families without consistent access to fresh, nutritious meals. Community hospitals are closing, severing vital lifelines in already underserved regions. Yet some still politicize equity, treating it as a threat rather than the foundation of a just healthcare system.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_3":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_3","name":"7b98","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"But to me, health equity isn‚Äôt political.\nIt‚Äôs personal.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_4":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_4","name":"0397","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"A Tale of a Few Cities","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_5":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_5","name":"5b27","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Before I was a healthcare leader, I was a 19-year-old trying to survive in a system never designed for people like me.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_6":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_6","name":"b9ae","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Born in Ukraine, raised in Jamaica, and shaped by a stepfather from Palestine, my life gave me a deeply global and intersectional perspective on health and justice. Each place revealed how identity, politics, and history decide who gets care ‚Äî and who doesn‚Äôt.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*LJhw43QVk7ecTzXqWPjniA.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*LJhw43QVk7ecTzXqWPjniA.jpeg","originalHeight":3024,"originalWidth":4032,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_7":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_7","name":"2171","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*LJhw43QVk7ecTzXqWPjniA.jpeg"},"text":"","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_8":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_8","name":"6804","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In Ukraine, I was born into a post-Soviet health system marked by scarcity, where underfunded institutions struggled to meet basic needs. In Jamaica, I witnessed how colonial legacies and chronic underinvestment led to shortages and a brain drain as healthcare workers left seeking stability. Through my stepfather‚Äôs Palestinian heritage, I learned health is not just clinical care ‚Äî it is a human right, one threatened daily by occupation, displacement, and systemic violence.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_9":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_9","name":"55a9","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"These experiences root my commitment to health equity as a global imperative ‚Äî one demanding structural change and deep cultural humility.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_10":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_10","name":"2a8a","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"From Survival to Awareness","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_11":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_11","name":"3e9f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"As a teenager, my family moved to California, where my immigrant parents ‚Äî skilled professionals abroad ‚Äî struggled to find work that reflected their expertise. From 14, I saw how hard it was to start over in a system that didn‚Äôt recognize our worth.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_12":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_12","name":"7dec","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"We were poor. My parents were often sick. It fell to me to find a way forward.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_13":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_13","name":"633f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"At 19, I landed a job at a multinational logistics company earning $12.50 an hour, just 50 cents more than my previous banking job. That small raise allowed me to leave a friend‚Äôs couch in San Bernardino and rent a cramped 200-square-foot studio in Chula Vista, a working-class border community.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_14":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_14","name":"7c84","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"From my door, I could see the Mexican flag waving in the wind. Some nights, staring at it, I‚Äôd wonder what happens next.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_15":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_15","name":"d733","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"By day, I worked in La Jolla ‚Äî an upscale enclave with boutique cafes, luxury cars, and oceanfront mansions. People there moved differently. They smiled more, lived longer, bought fresh food without a second thought.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_16":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_16","name":"bfc2","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Back in Chula Vista, I rationed food and gas. I survived mostly on baked potatoes, sometimes with butter and cheese if I was lucky. I breathed in pollution, battled roaches, and pushed through fatigue.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_17":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_17","name":"2589","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"At 19, I didn‚Äôt understand why I felt so worn down. Now, I know: I was living the embodied toll of inequality.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_18":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_18","name":"24dc","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Physical Toll of Inequality","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_19":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_19","name":"57e1","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Pelvic pain from heavy lifting turned into a hairline fracture, then a full one. Signs of hypertension were missed for years, eventually leading to heart issues. These weren‚Äôt isolated health events ‚Äî they were consequences of working-class precarity, food insecurity, and stress.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_20":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_20","name":"f85b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Whenever I walked through La Jolla or visited a Whole Foods, I felt a sharp contrast. Their health was supported by environment and access. Mine was deteriorating from deprivation.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_21":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_21","name":"1d24","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I didn‚Äôt know about social programs that could‚Äôve helped. I wasn‚Äôt aware of how deeply the places we live, work, and grow shape our health. If I could go back, I‚Äôd want that knowledge early ‚Äî because education could‚Äôve made my path easier.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_22":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_22","name":"2af2","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Cost of Inequality ‚Äî Locally and Globally","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_23":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_23","name":"7195","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"What I experienced was more than poverty. It was a textbook example of how social determinants of health shape up to 80% of health outcomes, according to the CDC.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_24":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_24","name":"9763","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And this reality is not confined to the U.S.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_25":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_25","name":"2b4b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In Jamaica, underfunded systems, medical shortages, and climate change strain already fragile infrastructure.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":3,"end":10,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_26":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_26","name":"5cd6","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In Ukraine, just before the 2022 invasion, my parents received exceptional post-operative care. But war has turned healthcare into a humanitarian crisis ‚Äî interrupting treatments, displacing providers, and making care increasingly unaffordable. My grandmother, living on a $50 monthly pension, now faces soaring medical costs she cannot pay.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":3,"end":10,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_27":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_27","name":"4691","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In Gaza, the health system is collapsing under siege. Hospitals have been bombed, doctors killed, and access to food, water, and care deliberately blocked. There is no neutrality in the destruction of healthcare.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":3,"end":7,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_28":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_28","name":"af3b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In all these places, injustice, violence, and economic constraint deepen inequities. These are not isolated crises. They are global echoes of systemic failure.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_29":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_29","name":"9b29","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Closer to home, in California, Chula Vista had been redlined for decades, starved of investment. It remains a food desert, with poor housing and limited care. Just 20 miles away, La Jolla flourishes.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":31,"end":42,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":179,"end":187,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_30":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_30","name":"526d","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The difference between these zip codes isn‚Äôt just income ‚Äî it‚Äôs life expectancy. In California, people in wealthier neighborhoods live 10 to 15 years longer than those in historically disinvested ones.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_31":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_31","name":"08c0","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Equity Is Not Up for Debate","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_32":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_32","name":"a17d","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Despite overwhelming evidence, health equity faces fierce political attack. What was once a moral and public health imperative is now dismissed as divisive. But acknowledging the disproportionate harm faced by marginalized communities isn‚Äôt controversial ‚Äî it‚Äôs responsible.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_33":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_33","name":"1794","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Research shows that chronic exposure to racism, poverty, and instability ‚Äî what scholars call ‚Äúweathering‚Äù ‚Äî leads to early chronic illness, higher hypertension, and increased maternal mortality.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_34":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_34","name":"9ea6","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Yet across the country, there are efforts to erase these truths. Public health agencies are pressured to remove ‚Äúequity‚Äù from strategic plans. DEI programs are being dismantled. Some states have banned DEI language entirely. Over 20 million people risk losing Medicaid coverage due to rollbacks ‚Äî harming Black, Brown, and low-income communities most. And Black women remain three times more likely than white women to die from pregnancy-related causes, regardless of income or education.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_35":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_35","name":"4568","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"These are not abstract debates. They are life-and-death decisions about who is seen, who is cared for, and who survives.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_36":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_36","name":"a4da","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Foundation of a Just Healthcare System","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_37":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_37","name":"9838","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Health equity is not charity. It‚Äôs not a luxury. It‚Äôs the foundation of a functioning healthcare system.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_38":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_38","name":"125e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"When everyone has access to preventive care, fresh food, clean air, and stable housing, society benefits. Life expectancy improves. Productivity rises. Healthcare costs fall.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_39":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_39","name":"e0fb","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Solutions exist:\n‚Äì Expand Medicaid access\n‚Äì Invest in culturally competent care\n‚Äì Reverse redlining through community development\n‚Äì Protect DEI initiatives in health institutions","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_40":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_40","name":"1d76","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"These are practical, evidence-based steps toward fairness.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_41":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_41","name":"6e98","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Urgency of Now","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_42":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_42","name":"0c2a","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The question isn‚Äôt whether health equity matters. It‚Äôs whether we have the courage to fight for it.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_43":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_43","name":"b84e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Will we listen to communities in crisis? Will we protect policies that guarantee fair access to care?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_44":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_44","name":"d66c","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I know the road ahead will be hard. But I also know this: I will not be silent.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":58,"end":78,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_45":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_45","name":"f63b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"To every policymaker, healthcare leader, advocate, and organizer: I invite you to stand with me.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:a264f9ea8b9d_46":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"a264f9ea8b9d_46","name":"af62","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Because key_insights: Personal narrative connecting lived experience of poverty and health inequity across multiple countries (Ukraine, Jamaica, Palestine, USA)
Social determinants of health account for up to 80% of health outcomes according to CDC
Geographic health disparities: people in wealthier California neighborhoods live 10-15 years longer than those in disinvested areas
Current political attacks on health equity initiatives including DEI program dismantling and removal of equity language from public health plans
Over 20 million people at risk of losing Medicaid coverage; Black women 3x more likely to die from pregnancy-related causes
Health equity framed as foundation of functioning healthcare system, not charity or luxury
Practical solutions proposed: expand Medicaid, invest in culturally competent care, reverse redlining, protect DEI initiatives
summary: A personal essay by Samantha Truman, founder of True People Consulting, arguing that health equity is not a political issue but a fundamental requirement for a just healthcare system. Drawing on her experiences growing up in Ukraine, Jamaica, and as a low-income worker in California, she illustrates how social determinants of health create stark disparities in outcomes. The article critiques current political efforts to dismantle DEI programs and equity initiatives while millions face Medicaid cuts and food insecurity, calling for systemic change and advocacy.

Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon From Burnout to Breakthrough: How Gen Z and Millennials Sparked a Workplace Renaissance Samantha Truman 4 min read ¬∑ Aug 27, 2025 -- Listen Share History likes to fool us. We look back at the Renaissance and imagine it as a single turning point ‚Äî Michelangelo, da Vinci, the printing press, all arriving in some great coordinated leap forward. But that‚Äôs not how it felt for the people living it. They weren‚Äôt calling it a renaissance yet. They were just pushing against the limits of their time. We‚Äôre in that same place right now. Not ‚Äúapproaching a renaissance.‚Äù Not ‚Äúwaiting for it by 2030.‚Äù The signals are already here ‚Äî flashing across work, culture, politics, art, and technology ‚Äî and most leaders are missing them. Press enter or click to view image in full size On the Sistine Chapel ceiling, Michelangelo‚Äôs Creation of Adam (1508‚Äì1512) captures the moment when God‚Äôs touch awakens humanity, depicting the Genesis story of giving life to the first man, Adam. What Makes a Renaissance? If you strip the romance from the history books, the Renaissance was triggered by a few key forces: New tools for knowledge: The printing press democratized information. Shifts in power: The old guard (church, monarchs) lost their monopoly on truth. Cultural hunger: After centuries of the Dark Ages, people were desperate for light, art, and meaning. Sound familiar? In 2025, we‚Äôre living through the same pattern: Our printing press: AI, automation, and digital platforms. Our power shifts: From legacy corporations to decentralized creators and startups. Our hunger: Burned-out generations refusing to work without purpose. That‚Äôs not future tense. That‚Äôs now. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman with Child (2022). Photograph capturing the emergence of a new renaissance ‚Äî technology as our digital press, and millennials reshaping work with purpose. The Cues You‚Äôre Ignoring Look around. You‚Äôll see signs of renaissance everywhere ‚Äî but they don‚Äôt always look like corporate ‚Äúinnovation.‚Äù The Creator Economy: Millions leaving stable jobs to build on Patreon, Substack, TikTok, or Shopify. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúcontent‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs economic reformation. The Union Resurgence: From Starbucks to tech firms, Gen Z and Millennials are resurrecting collective action that‚Äôs been dormant for decades. The Spiritual Search: Google Trends shows spikes in words like purpose, meaning, consciousness . Entire generations are asking questions about life‚Äôs why, not just life‚Äôs how. The 4-Day Workweek Experiments: What was once a fringe idea is now piloted by hundreds of companies worldwide. Productivity didn‚Äôt collapse. In most cases, it soared. These are not isolated events. They‚Äôre brushstrokes in a larger painting: people are refusing to stay in dark, extractive systems. Why Most Leaders Are Blind to It Here‚Äôs the irony: when you‚Äôre inside a system, it feels permanent. That‚Äôs why medieval leaders laughed at the printing press ‚Äî they couldn‚Äôt imagine a world where peasants read. Today‚Äôs equivalent? Leaders who scoff at AI, or dismiss cultural demands for flexibility as ‚Äúentitlement.‚Äù They‚Äôre making the same mistake: confusing the collapse of their system with the collapse of all systems. But what‚Äôs happening is the opposite. We‚Äôre not collapsing. We‚Äôre reinventing. Press enter or click to view image in full size Man Meets Machine (2025). Medieval leaders scoffed at peasants reading; today‚Äôs scoff at AI and flexible work. The hand we‚Äôre reaching for isn‚Äôt collapse ‚Äî it‚Äôs the next renaissance. The Four Signals of a Workplace Renaissance After 15 years of studying organizational culture, I see four clear signals that prove the renaissance is here: Tech-Human Fusion AI isn‚Äôt replacing humans; it‚Äôs re-centering what makes us human ‚Äî creativity, connection, judgment. The leaders who get this will unlock abundance. The Dignity Revolt People aren‚Äôt begging for beanbags and pizza parties. They‚Äôre demanding dignity ‚Äî safety, belonging, fair pay, meaningful work. That‚Äôs the true employee ‚Äúperk.‚Äù The Purpose Economy From Gen Z entrepreneurs to investors backing climate-positive startups, value is shifting toward organizations that serve human and planetary needs, not just profit. New Leadership Archetypes The old command-and-control executive is fading. What‚Äôs emerging? Leaders fluent in cultural intelligence ‚Äî those who can navigate race, gender, power, tech, and meaning with equal fluency. The Cost of Missing the Moment History remembers the builders, not the deniers. The leaders who thought the printing press was a fad didn‚Äôt just lose power ‚Äî they lost relevance. The same will be true in 2030. Those who cling to legacy management, extraction-based work, and fear-driven cultures will not just lose talent. They‚Äôll lose the ability to function in the new economy. What Renaissance Leadership Looks Like Now This isn‚Äôt a five-year plan. It‚Äôs a current posture. Renaissance leaders are already: Encouraging experimentation with AI tools, not policing them. Treating cultural health as infrastructure, not an HR checkbox. Linking strategy to human purpose, not just shareholder return. Measuring success not just by growth, but by the human flourishing inside their systems. Don‚Äôt Wait for 2030 The renaissance doesn‚Äôt begin in five years. It begins with the decisions you make this quarter. The question isn‚Äôt: Will there be a workplace renaissance? The question is: Will you recognize you‚Äôre already in one? Because history is already being written. And your organization‚Äôs name is either going to be in the chapter on those who adapted ‚Äî or those who disappeared. Leaders who wait will miss it. Leaders who see the Renaissance unfolding will shape it. Follow me on LinkedIn for practical insights, and on Substack for deeper essays. Don‚Äôt just watch history ‚Äî help write it. key_insights: We are currently experiencing a workplace renaissance driven by Gen Z and Millennials, not waiting for one in the future
Four key signals indicate workplace transformation: Tech-Human Fusion, Dignity Revolt, Purpose Economy, and New Leadership Archetypes
Modern workplace renaissance mirrors historical Renaissance patterns: new tools (AI), power shifts (decentralized work), and cultural hunger (purpose-driven work)
Leaders who dismiss cultural demands for flexibility and AI integration risk organizational irrelevance
Renaissance leadership focuses on experimentation, cultural health as infrastructure, human purpose, and measuring human flourishing
The creator economy, union resurgence, spiritual search, and 4-day workweek experiments are signs of systemic workplace reinvention
Organizations must adapt now rather than wait, as history is being written in real-time
summary: This thought leadership article argues that we are currently living through a workplace renaissance sparked by Gen Z and Millennials, drawing parallels to the historical Renaissance. The author identifies four clear signals of transformation: Tech-Human Fusion, the Dignity Revolt, the Purpose Economy, and New Leadership Archetypes. The piece challenges leaders to recognize ongoing workplace transformation rather than dismissing it, emphasizing that organizations must adapt immediately to avoid irrelevance. It highlights concrete examples like the creator economy, union resurgence, and 4-day workweek experiments as evidence of systemic change already underway.
